text: Your Thursday Evening BriefingHere’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
Listen to ‘The Daily’The candidates, part 1: Donald Trump’s promises.
Listen to ‘Sway’ With Kara SwisherCan big tech make sure that 2020 is not 2016?

Tonight at 8 PM EDT
			Follow along for live analysis as President Trump and Joe Biden host dueling town halls.
Live Analysis and Fact Checks From Our ReportersTimes journalists will be watching both candidates. Follow along here.
NBC, Under Fire for Trump Event, Faces a Big TestRachel Maddow of MSNBC criticized the decision to air the town hall opposite ABC’s Biden forum tonight.

Christie Says He Was ‘Wrong’ Not to Wear Masks at White HouseChris Christie, the former New Jersey governor who was hospitalized as he battled Covid-19, urged people to follow C.D.C. guidelines in public.
Lindsey Graham Leads Jaime Harrison in South Carolina Race, Poll ShowsSenator Lindsey Graham, in a tough fight for re-election, is ahead by six percentage points, our poll found.

Inspired by Trump, Hasidic Backlash Grows Over N.Y.C. Virus RulesOrthodox Jewish leaders have seen a growing, raucous faction of men in the community, tired of virus guidelines and resentful of authorities.
A college president in New York resigned after 700 students tested positive for the virus.

Republicans Clash on Stimulus as Trump Says ‘Go Big’ and McConnell DemursPresident Trump called for a plan of the kind envisioned by Democrats. Senator Mitch McConnell said Republicans could not accept so large a deal.
The relentlessly high level of claims for state jobless benefits indicates a labor market that “appears to be stalled,” one economist said. Angela Weiss/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

Facebook and Twitter Dodge a 2016 Repeat, and Ignite a 2020 FirestormThe companies have said they would do more to stop misinformation and hacked materials from spreading. This is what that effort looks like, our tech columnist writes.
Republicans criticized Facebook and Twitter after the sites blocked an unsubstantiated New York Post article.
Judge Amy Coney Barrett during the third day of confirmation hearings on Wednesday. Erin Schaff/The New York Times
Analysis: 18 Hours of Questions, Few AnswersJudge Amy Coney Barrett took a rigorous approach to the strategy used by all modern Supreme Court nominees: avoiding taking a stance on most issues.
Senate Republicans set a vote on Oct. 22 for Judge Amy Coney Barrett’s confirmation, blowing past Democrats’ objections.
Matthew McConaughey knows there are people who think he “just eases right into everything.” He said he wrote “Greenlights” partly as a corrective. Devin Oktar Yalkin for The New York Times
John Fabian WittRepublican Judges Are Quietly Upending Public Health LawsA catastrophic sequence of decisions has blocked states from responding to the pandemic.
Moises Velasquez-Manoff5 Ways to Focus Your Angst and Energy Before Nov. 3Giving money is fine, but you can also donate your energy.
Stephen WertheimThe U.S. Has No Reason to Be So Powerful
David BrooksHow to Actually Make America Great
Paul KrugmanThe G.O.P. Can Still Wreck This Country
Samara Klar and Christopher WeberWhy Would a Republican Vote Biden? Ask Arizonans
Gail CollinsVotes, Sex and Money
Aaron E. CarrollKids Have Suffered Enough. Let Them Have Halloween.
Charles M. BlowMy Brother Died and Reminded Me of These Life Lessons
Jennifer SeniorRod Rosenstein Was Just Doing His Job
Rick BlakeJacob Blake Is My Nephew. My Family Is Suffering.
This Urban Safari Comes With a Warning: Watch Out for SnakesOn nighttime hikes in Hong Kong’s surprisingly lush forests, a snake catcher teaches city slickers about the reptiles — and their bites.

Here’s What It’s Like to Appear on ‘Curb Your Enthusiasm’The HBO comedy premiered 20 years ago. Bryan Cranston, Ricky Gervais, Judge Judy, Kym Whitley and others describe how it feels to face off with Larry David.

A $5 rapid coronavirus test may be nearly as effective as a slower, more complex test, one study found.
